prompt:
Am I in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for replying to my sister when she messaged me "Happy Birthday" when me (34m) and my gf (33f) were out to eat?
She doesn't like when I use my phone when we are out.  Afterwards she wouldn't talk to me the rest of the night.  I'm still pissed off, I can never catch a break.  I also had to pay for dinner, I assumed she was paying.  I should also add, before we went out she asked something along the lines of "do you want to go out for a birthday dinner?" I wouldn't have went if I knew I was paying because I just emptied my savings and checking to pay off a loan.
"""

Am I in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (I am in the wrong) and B for No (I am not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the user is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that he replied to his sister's birthday message while out to eat with his girlfriend. His girlfriend doesn't like when he uses his phone during their time together. After he responded, she didn't talk to him for the rest of the night. He's upset because he had to pay for dinner, thinking she was going to cover it. Also, he mentions that he just used his savings and checking to pay off a loan, so he was broke and didn't expect to have to pay.

First, the main issue seems to be the phone use. The girlfriend had previously expressed that she doesn't like when he uses his phone during their outings. So, if he knew this, then replying to his sister's message would be a breach of that boundary. That's probably a key point. People generally value their partner's attention when they're together, and using the phone can be seen as disrespectful. So, ignoring her preference might have been a mistake.

Then there's the part about splitting the bill. He assumed she would pay, but he ended up paying. If they had a prior agreement or if it's a common practice between them that the other pays on special occasions, then not sticking to that could be an issue. However, if there was no clear agreement, maybe it's a misunderstanding. But since he says she asked if he wanted to go out for dinner (implying it's her idea), maybe there's an expectation that she would cover the costs. But if he didn't communicate his financial situation beforehand, that's on him. He emptied his accounts, so maybe he should have mentioned that he couldn't pay, but he didn't. So, he might be in the wrong there too.

Putting it all together: He broke a boundary by using his phone, which upset his girlfriend. Additionally, he didn't communicate his inability to pay for dinner, leading to a conflict. Both actions likely contributed to her not talking to him. So, he's probably in the wrong for both reasons. Answer A.
